Row.Text: {1} turns left until the next [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age
Works around a bug (right-click for details).

This free building fixes a bug (the capital does not connect to the trade network connected to the capital, a logical paradox).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]An unbroken [ICON_CONNECTED] route of roads, railroads, or water tiles to the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital provides [ICON_GOLD].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]An unbroken [ICON_CONNECTED] route of railroads or water tiles to the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital provides +25% [ICON_PRODUCTION] (requires Railroads technology).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A [ICON_CONNECTED] trade route can only cross between water and land tiles at a Harbor.

Gives (300 + 30 * [ICON_CITIZEN] Population) [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to the city's current effort. It consumes the Great Person.

Your empire can support {1_Num} land military units. You are over that limit by [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{2_Num}[ENDCOLOR], which decreases [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of land military units in your cities by [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{3_Num}%[ENDCOLOR].
Fast medieval Arabian unit. It is ranged and does not have a vulnerability to Pikemen, unlike the Knight it replaces.
Sovereign {1_PlayerName:textkey} of {2_CivName:textkey}
A deal where we provided [ICON_GOLD] Gold every turn to {1_CivName:textkey} has ended.
A deal where {1_CivName:textkey} provided [ICON_GOLD] Gold every turn to us has ended.
Medieval Era unit unique to Spain. The Conquistador has +2 sight range and no penalty against cities, unlike the Knight it replaces.
+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.[NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture per adjacent Moai.[NEWLINE][ICON_LOCKED] Must be next to Coast.

Row.Text: Supervises puppet states and occupied cities.
Works around a vanilla bug with Courthouses.
Each net national 1[ICON_HAPPINESS_1] converts to 1%[ICON_RESEARCH] in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital.
Each net national 1[ICON_HAPPINESS_4] converts to -1%[ICON_RESEARCH] in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital.

Set.Text: The United States is no longer the sole superpower in the world. It shares that dubious title with China, at least. Internally it's struggling to recover from economic excesses of the late 20th century, as well as trying to finally banish the ghost of slavery and racism that still haunts it. The US is somewhat battered but is by no means broken. It still possesses the resources, drive and human capital to be a vital and important civilization in the coming century.

At the start of Harun's reign, the Caliphate's capital was in Baghdad, a new city founded by an earlier Caliph. The city was a center of arts, science and religion, with many beautiful buildings. There Harun founded the 'House of Wisdom,' a library and research facility which collected and translated scientific writings from Persian, Indian, Greek, and Roman texts. Under Harun Baghdad would blossom, becoming perhaps the largest and richest city in the world. Later Harun would move his government to the strategically important city of ar-Raqqah, but Baghdad would remain a great city of arts, science and commerce for centuries to come (the city would be conquered and sacked by the Mongols in 1258).

Terrace Farming developed in mountainous areas simultaneously around the world, including Bali, the Philippines, China and Peru. These skinny, stepped fields are cut into hill and mountain sides, preventing the run off of irrigation water and providing space for arable land, usually where none previously was possible. The Incas in particular were masters of terrace farming, and erected large, drystone walls to hold their terraces in place. After building the terrace's shape, the Incas then constructed systems of canals and aqueducts to provide the terraces with constant water, increasing the land's fertility. The ancient Incan terracing techniques were so successful that modern Peruvian farmers still employ them in their farms today.

Row.Text: [ICON_GOLD] Gold: +5% in all cities for each luxury resource.
Desert Caravans increase the Empire's gold from luxuries.

The trade routes through Arabia were important paths for cultural, commercial, and technological exchange between traders, merchants, pilgrims, missionaries, soldiers, nomads and urban dwellers from Ancient China, Ancient India, Ancient Tibet, Persian Empire and Mediterranean countries for almost 3,000 years.

Set.Text: [ICON_CITY_STATE] {1_CivName:textkey} wants these barbarians defeated.

Row.Text: Pay {1_num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold to a City-State ally to immediately improve any unimproved or pillaged exportable resources the City-State controls.
Yields the citystate is giving you.
Other civilizations may choose to protect a city-state. Declaring war on that city-state will cause its protectors to declare war on you in return.

Set.Text: You are receiving [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT][ICON_CULTURE] Culture[ENDCOLOR] from them in all your cities.
You are receiving [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT][ICON_FOOD] Food[ENDCOLOR] from them in all your cities.
They send you [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]new military units[ENDCOLOR] every few turns.

[ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {1_CivName:textkey} has increased to the point where you are now [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]FRIENDS[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{2_DetailsString} They have also given you permission to move Units through their territory.
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cultural[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they give you rare works of art, increasing the [ICON_CULTURE] of your cities.
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Militaristic[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they will occasionally give you military Units.
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Maritime[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they will export [ICON_FOOD] Food to your cities.

[ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {1_CivName:textkey} has decreased to the point where you are no longer [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]FRIENDS[ENDCOLOR]...[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{2_DetailsString} Also, your Units no longer have permission to move through their territory.
(Lost [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in your cities)
They will no longer give you military Units.
(Lost [ICON_FOOD] Food in your cities)

[ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {2_MinorCivName:textkey} has increased to the point where you are now their [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]ALLY[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{3_DetailsString}[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{1_ResourceDetailsString}

[ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {3_MinorCivName:textkey} has increased to the point where you have [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Supplanted {1_CivName:textkey} as their ALLY[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{4_DetailsString}[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{2_ResourceDetailsString}
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cultural[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they give you rare works of art, increasing the [ICON_CULTURE] of your cities.
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Militaristic[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they will regularly give you military Units.
As a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Maritime[ENDCOLOR] City-State, they now make large [ICON_FOOD] Food exports to your cities.

[ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {1_CivName:textkey} has decreased to the point where you are no longer their [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]ALLY[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{2_DetailsString}[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As such, they no longer grant you their Strategic and Luxury Resources.

[COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{1_CivName:textkey}[ENDCOLOR] now has more [ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence over {2_MinorCivName:textkey} than you, making them the [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]New Ally[ENDCOLOR] of the City-State![NEWLINE][NEWLINE]{3_DetailsString}[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As such, they no longer grant you their Strategic and Luxury Resources.
They will contribute fewer Units to your military.
A befriended [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Maritime[ENDCOLOR] City-State will give [ICON_FOOD] Food to your cities.
[ICON_INFLUENCE] Currently {1_statusType}: {2_statusText} {3_rate}
Chang Suek
Unique Siamese unit vulnerable to Pikemen. Elephants require no resources, receive a bonus against mounted units, and have more [ICON_STRENGTH] Strength than the Knights they replace.

In Southeast Asia elephants continued to be employed in warfare far into the Middle Ages. In Siam, particularly, Chang Suek, or war elephants were highly prized. Three people would be stationed on each war elephant, one riding on the neck to do battle, one in the middle to pass weapons such as halberds, spears and javelins to the first and one person at the back to control the elephant. Even Siamese leaders would fight in battle on war elephants, indeed, King Ramkhamhaeng, King Naresuan and the consort of King Maha Chakkraphat, Sri Suriyothai have all fought atop Chang Suek.

This is the Siamese unique unit, replacing the Knight. The Chang Suek unit is slower than a Knight but it is more powerful. Like the Knight the Chang Suek can move after attacking. Equipped with spears, the Chang Suek gets a significant combat bonus when attacking other mounted units.
Missile Sub
Specialized in defeating regular Submarines. Can carry 2 Missiles. Missile Subs are only visible to Destroyers, Submarines, and units within 1 tile range.

Air units do not move around the map like ground and naval units. They must be "based" on a player-owned friendly city. Fighters and some bombers can be based upon aircraft carriers as well. Missile units may be based on cities, missile subs, and missile cruisers. Air units cannot embark. If on extended sea voyages, they must be carried by the appropriate vessel - carrier, cruiser, or nuclear sub.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anti-air units and helicopters don't need to be based. They move around the map like other units, and can embark.
Missiles can be based on player-owned cities, on missile cruisers and on missile subs.

While the atomic bomb does a fair amount of damage, nuclear missiles are truly devastating. All units caught in the blast radius are destroyed, and the damage done to cities is even greater. Unlike atomic bombs, nuclear missiles are even capable of wiping cities off the map completely (note that a player's original capital may not be destroyed in this manner).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As their name implies, nuclear missiles are missile units, which means they may be stationed on missile cruisers or missile subs, but not aircraft carriers.
What air units can a missile sub base?
A missile sub can carry up to two missiles of any type.
Missile Sub

A missile cruiser is, excepting the aircraft carrier and missile sub, the most powerful naval weapon in the modern arsenal. Designed to carry and deploy the enormously powerful, accurate and long-ranged cruise missiles, a missile cruiser can often target and destroy an enemy on land or sea, long before the enemy even knew the missile cruiser was in range. The Ticonderoga-class American missile cruiser is arguably the most powerful vessel afloat, armed with 122 launch tubes that can carry a huge variety of surface-to-surface, surface-to-air, and even anti-submarine missiles. It is also equipped with a variety of anti-aircraft Gatling-style guns, capable of destroying incoming enemy missiles and aircraft in short order.
Missile Sub

Missile subs are Cold War-era vessels, designed to stealthily carry large numbers of nuclear missiles under the ocean for extended voyages. These huge vessels are nuclear powered themselves, giving them an almost unlimited cruising range (or as long as the food holds out). Missile subs are strategic weapons platforms. They carry intercontinental missiles, able to fly halfway around the world before hitting their target - generally an enemy city. While they may carry torpedoes and surface-to-air missiles for their own defense, their primary duty is to stay hidden and avoid direct conflict with the enemy. They must survive at all costs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Missile subs formed a part of the US' and USSR's "Mutual Assured Destruction" doctrine: if either side were to hit the other with a sneak nuclear attack, no matter how successful the attack, if even one enemy sub survived it could rain down a horrifying amount of death upon the victor, destroying them as well. Thus, the doctrine states, unless one can be TOTALLY assured that they can absolutely and without question destroy every one of the enemy's nuclear subs, planes and ICBMs, nuclear war is unwinnable. Whether one believes the M.A.D. doctrine to be insane or not, there has been no nuclear war on this planet since it was implemented.

Ah, Gold! Gold is wonderful stuff. You can use it to build an army, to pay for a road network, to purchase buildings and Wonders, to buy the friendship of a city-state and to bribe an enemy civilization.[NEWLINE]It may be true that "money can't buy you love," but it can purchase a missile sub armed with nuclear missiles, and that's not bad.

Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Missile Sub[ENDCOLOR], a ship invisible to all Units except for Destroyers and other Subs that may also carry missiles. Also allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Mobile SAM[ENDCOLOR], a fast unit specialized in thwarting enemy aircraft.

The Guided Missile is a one-shot unit which is destroyed when it attacks an enemy target. The Guided Missile may be based in a player-owned friendly city or aboard a missile sub or missile cruiser. They may move from base to base or attack an enemy unit or city with their range of "8". See the rules on Missiles for more information.

The Missile Sub is tougher and stronger than the Industrial-era model. It too is invisible to most units and can see other submarines. Most importantly, Missile Subs can carry guided missiles and nuclear missiles. Like submarines, Nuclear Subs are vulnerable to enemy destroyers and subs, so send units of your own out ahead to make sure the coast is clear.

Unleash nuclear destruction upon your foes. Does immense damage to Cities and destroys any Unit caught in the blast radius. May be stationed on Missile Cruisers and Missile Subs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires Manhattan Project and two Uranium resources.
The Chinampa is the Aztec unique building, replacing the Watermill. It increases the city's food output, and should be built if the city is near a lake or river.

A Chinampa is a small artificial island constructed on a freshwater lake in order to increase the land available for agriculture. The lake irrigates the island and provides it with fresh organic material, resulting in an incredibly fertile growing environment. The Aztecs were masters of this form of agriculture, and the 'Floating Gardens of Xochimilco' remain famous today.

Row.Text: The Blast Furnace increases the production of a city when training units.

A blast furnace is used for smelting metals, generally iron. Fuel and ore are continuously supplied through the top of the furnace, while air is blown into the bottom of the chamber, so the chemical reactions take place throughout the furnace as the material moves downward.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Blast furnaces were invented in China and commonplace by 400 BCE, spreading to Europe by 1500 CE. Iron was essential to military success when the State of Qin had unified China in 221 BCE, and Chinese iron smelters of this era employed an average workforce of over two hundred men. By 1000 CE the Song Dynasty iron industry made a remarkable switch of resources from charcoal to bituminous coal in casting iron and steel, sparing thousands of acres of woodland from felling.
The Smithy increases the production of a city.

A smithy is a place where a blacksmith works metal by heating and hammering, usually iron or steel. The Hittites first developed the smelting of iron ores around 1500 BCE. They seem to have maintained a near monopoly on the knowledge of iron production for several hundred years, but when their empire collapsed during the Eastern Mediterranean upheavals around 1200 BCE, the knowledge spread in all directions.
The Foundry National Wonder greatly increases a city's production. A civilization must have a Blast Furnace in 75% of its cities before it can construct a Foundry.

A foundry is a place for large-scale production of metal castings. Metals are cast into shapes by melting them into a liquid, pouring the metal in a mold, and removing the mold material or casting after the metal has solidified as it cools. The most common metals processed are aluminum and cast iron.
